TI: Tetrahydrocurcumin confers protection against amyloid beta-induced toxicity.
AB: Amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are the hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease. Amyloid beta, a primary component of the amyloid plaques, is neurotoxic. Considerable attention has been directed toward identifying compounds with neuroprotective properties. Using rat primary hippocampal cultures, we show that tetrahydrocurcumin (THC), a metabolite of curcumin, shows a protective effect against oligomeric amyloid-beta-induced toxicity. We further show that THC reduces amyloid-beta-induced (i) increase in the level of reactive oxygen species, (ii) decrease in mitochondrial membrane potential, and (iii) caspase activation. In addition, we show that THC protects human neurons from oligomeric amyloid-beta-induced toxicity as well. Thus, THC confers protection against amyloid-beta-induced toxicity, and the antioxidant activity may contribute to its protective effect.
AD: National Brain Research Centre, Manesar, Haryana, India.
